nodes.text: Preferences are representable by a unique ergodic transformation exactly when they satisfy a small set of axioms, yielding a representation where maximizing expected transformed wealth equals maximizing the time-average growth rate

I axiomatize preferences on stochastic wealth processes (SWPs) with five axioms (consistency, Archimedean, independence, monotonicity, ergodicity) to obtain a decision theory that pins down an ergodic transformation

Main formal result (Ergodic vNM): preferences satisfying axioms 3.1-3.5 are representable by a function f such that x preferred to x' iff E[f(xt)] >= E[f(x't)] and E[f(xt)] equals the long-run time-average growth rate of f(xt)
Lemma and mixture-space representation: under consistency, Archimedean and independence the preference preorder on the mixture space is represented by a linear functional L

Application to Ito processes: given dx = a(x)dt + b(x)dW, an ergodic transform f exists when a and b satisfy a(x) = (alpha/beta) b(x) + b(x) b'(x)/2, yielding df = alpha dt + beta dW and constant drift/diffusion for f

Empirical context: Copenhagen Experiment reported subjects adapt utility functions to render observed wealth dynamics ergodic (log for multiplicative, identity for additive), motivating normative axiomatization of Ergodicity Economics

Comparative claim: the axiomatized ergodic framework should be compared normatively to temporal vNM (multi-period expected utility) and descriptively to dynamic ambiguity aversion; appendix compares CE to multi-period EUT

Axiom set summary: Consistency (complete preorder), Archimedean (continuity via mixtures), Independence (mixture independence), Monotonicity (prefer more to less at each time), Ergodicity (rankings follow long-run time-average growth of transformed SWP)

Mixture Space Theorem: a complete preorder on the mixture space satisfying consistency and independence implies existence of a linear functional L mapping SWPs to real numbers that represents preferences
Lemma 3.1: mixture monotonicity properties ensure uniqueness of mixing weights and continuity properties used to construct L

Conclusion: Under axioms 3.1-3.5 the representing function f is an ergodic transformation of the SWP, so maximizing expected f(xt) is normatively equivalent to maximizing long-run time-average growth; this pins down f but not traditional risk interpretation

Example result: for a contrived dynamic with b(x)=x^gamma one obtains f'(x)=1/b(x)=x^-gamma implying f(x)=x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma) (gamma !=1), recovering CRRA-type transform as an ergodic transformation rather than an attitude parameter
Copenhagen Experiment design: subjects experienced passive learning of image-to-wealth changes then chose between gambles over many trials; terminal wealth computed from selected outcomes
Empirical claim: CE findings (log for multiplicative, identity for additive) are consistent with agents maximizing time-average growth under appropriate dynamics, motivating ergodicity axiom

Comparison result: temporal vNM (Kreps-Porteus) can normatively capture dynamic choices with early resolution preferences and backward induction, but ergodic axiomatization differs by associating preferences directly with long-run growth via f

Limitations: reliance on asymptotic t->infinity despite pre-asymptotic life, omission of preferences for early resolution of uncertainty, assumption agents know true dynamics and objective uncertainty, and need to extend to ambiguity aversion/robustness
